newsitem.title: GEORGIA: Ex-Soviet Georgian sparkling wine plant for sale.
newsitem.headline: Ex-Soviet Georgian sparkling wine plant for sale.

text.p: The former Soviet republic of Georgia, looking to put some of the fizz back into its once-proud sparkling wines industry, opened an international investment tender for its main sparkling wines plant on Monday.

Emir Djugeli, the deputy property minister, said 75.9 percent of the state-owned Bagrationi 1882 plant, in the capital Tbilisi, had been put on the selling block. 24.1 percent of the shares will stay in government hands.
"The starting price is $1.7 million," he said.
Bids in the sale, which is fully open to foreigners with no restrictions, would close on September 10, with the winner to be announced that day.
The winner would be required to invest at least $10 million within three years.
The plant is the largest of its type in the Caucasus mountains region and has a capacity of 200 million bottles a year.
Djugeli said that before the break up of the former Soviet Union in 1991, Bagrationi 1882 mainly exported its output beyond the borders of the Soviet Union.
But production in recent years had sharply declined due to a lack of capital.
"The plant produced only 445,000 bottles in 1996," Djugeli said.
